document.text: years ago I had a business transaction with The Fanners National Bank here which also involved a like trans action through The State Bank of Pamplin in which several hundred dollars was involved which after some reflection and checking up on my part I felt and was of the opinion that an error of several hundred dollars had been made against me and, requested Mr. Harwood, cashier of The Farm ers National Bank to investigate the m atter thoroughly going back . over his records and see if any error had been made. Mr. Harwood informs me that he has made careful and pains taking research regarding this transaction and assures ihe that the transaction was correct, which explanation I accept and hereby make public the fact that I am now satisfied with his explana tion and wish to make public apology for any statement which luj.taignjthave made which would E ffect on any one with regard to, this business transaction. In fact, the wenther seems to brew at the higher levels, and the observations, obtained by small bal loons and kites, often give Informa tion unobtainable nt the level of the earths surface. 43 Balloon Stations Send Data. The data used In the npper-atr weather maps come to the weather bureau from forty-three halloon sta tions throughout the country. The army has eighteen, while the navy tins ten balloon stations and one air- nlane observer. It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried on four years ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are slow to express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. document.text: W. M. Thompson, Minister All services next Sunday as usual. The pastor will preach at both services on Sunday af ter which he will leave on a four weeks vacation. During lis absence he will preach at the Temple Baptist Church, Baltimore, and the Colgate University Church, Hamilton, N. Y. He will then return to Brookneal, Va, where he will conduct a two weeks revival meeting. Preaching services will be held in Liberty Church every Sunday during his ab sence except Sunday, July 28th when the preaching services will be omitted and Liberty members will attend the Me thodist revival meetings. An nouncements of supplies will be made later. The annual meeting of the Appomattox Baptist Associa tion will be held at Rice Wed nesday and Thursday, July 24 and 25. Local people who will take part on the program are Mr. R. L. Burke, who will present the report of the Ex ecutive Committee and Mr. A. R. Harwood who will present the report on Temperance and Social Service. Rev. W. M. Thompson will deliver the ad dress on Evangelism. Others expected to attend are Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Gills, Mr. and Mrs. T. A. Walton and Don Moses. The latter will present the re port on Sunday School work.

document.text: VIRGINIA In the Clerks Office of the Cir cuit Court of Appomattox County, on the 21st day of November, 1951. R. L. Burke, William W. Burke, The Bank of Appomattox, Plaintiff Against David W. Cawthorne, Mary I Cawthorne et als Defendants. The object of this suit is to ad judge the proper ownership and right to a certain diesel engine now in the possession of Oscar T. Jamer- son and which was formerly in the possession of David W. Cawthorne. Title and the right to the possession of the engine is claimed by the Plaintiffs to this action under a deed of trust executed by David W. Cawthorne to secure a debt. And it appearing by affidavit fil ed that David W. Cawthorne and Mary I. Cawthorne are not residents of this state, they, are hereby re quired to appear within ten days af ter the due publication of this order and do what is necessary to protect their interests. Teste
